Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Xamarin.Android designer: How to tell when in design mode" (#1778) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
I don't know if this is the right place for this question but I don't know where to find the team in charge of the Designer.

In MvvmCross we have a bunch of code that fails in the designer because we count on things set up in a certain way.  I want to be able to mock these so that we can at least get our widgets displaying something useful in design mode.  Android provides a `View.isInEditMode` but by that point it's too late (at least for a clean solution.  Is there any other way to determine if we are in the designer?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "xamarin-android uses out-of-sync API generator from java.interop" (#1759) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
There is a big problem in xamarin-android API (Mono.Android) now. https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/pull/1728 should have never been merged without merging https://github.com/xamarin/java.interop/pull/325 .

Next time API generation will be simply impossible.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "WPF cannot include Forms directly or through Shared library" (#2935) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description
Adding a Xamarin Form XAML/CS file directly to the your WPF project, or including one via direct reference to a shared class library, the file will not build: **error CS0103: The name 'InitializeComponent' does not exist in the current context**

(If instead you create a NetStandard 2.0 class library and reference the shared project there, then reference the NetStandard 2.0 library from the WPF project, everything builds.)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new WPF application from template, accept the defaults
2. Add a new Xamarin Forms xaml/cs Page to the project and make sure its build action is set to **Embedded resource**  and Custom tool to **MSBuild:UpdateDesignTimeXaml**
3. Build

### Expected Behavior
No errors

### Actual Behavior
error CS0103: The name 'InitializeComponent' does not exist in the current context

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: Tried with 3.x including 3.1 prereleases
- Last known good version: N/A
- IDE: VS2017 15.7.3
- Platform Target Frameworks: <!-- All that apply -->
  - WPF:  .Net 4.6.1
- Nuget Packages: Xamarin.Forms and Xamarin.Forms.Platform.WPF

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[UWP] ListView with null ItemsSource crashes on 3.0.0.530893" (#2929) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description

Creating a ListView with a null ItemsSource crashes with a NullReferenceException in the `ReloadData` method of the UWP ListViewRenderer.

**Exception Details:**
Message: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
Stack Trace:

       at Xamarin.Forms.Platform.UWP.ListViewRenderer.ReloadData()
       at Xamarin.Forms.Platform.UWP.ListViewRenderer.OnElementChanged(ElementChangedEventArgs`1 e)
       at Xamarin.Forms.Platform.UWP.VisualElementRenderer`2.SetElement(VisualElement element)
       at Xamarin.Forms.Platform.UWP.Platform.CreateRenderer(VisualElement element)
       at Xamarin.Forms.Platform.UWP.VisualElementPackager.OnChildAdded(Object sender, ElementEventArgs e)
       at Xamarin.Forms.Platform.UWP.VisualElementPackager.Load()
       at Xamarin.Forms.Platform.UWP.VisualElementRenderer`2.SetElement(VisualElement element)
       at Xamarin.Forms.Platform.UWP.Platform.CreateRenderer(VisualElement element)
       at Xamarin.Forms.Platform.UWP.VisualElementExtensions.GetOrCreateRenderer(VisualElement self)
       at Xamarin.Forms.Platform.UWP.Platform.<SetCurrent>d__55.MoveNext()
    --- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
       at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
       at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.AsyncMethodBuilderCore.<>c.<ThrowAsync>b__6_0(Object state)
       at System.Threading.WinRTSynchronizationContextBase.Invoker.InvokeCore()

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Add a ListView with no ItemsSource set to a page.
2. Run on UWP

### Expected Behavior

Page renders with empty ListView.

### Actual Behavior

App crashes on loading the ListView.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 3.0.0.530893
- Last known good version: 3.0.0.482510
- IDE: Visual Studio Enterprise 2017
- Platform Target Frameworks:
  - UWP: 16299
- NuGet Packages:
  - Microsoft.NETCore.UniversalWindowsPlatform v6.0.1
  - NETStandard.Library v2.0.1
  - Xamarin.Forms v3.0.0.530893

### Reproduction Link

[NullItemSourceCrash.zip](https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/files/2069684/NullItemSourceCrash.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[iOS] Secondary Toolbar Items overlapping" (#2798) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description
As originally reported at bugzilla 59868, toolbar items are still overlapping.
@samhouts 

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a Xamarin Forms App
2. Create a Page with 3 or more Toolbar Items that have images
3. Run it on iOS 11 Simulator or iPhone

### Expected Behavior
The Toolbar Items are shown side by side

### Actual Behavior
The Toolbar Items are overlapping

### Basic Information
- Version with issue: 2.5 and newer
- Last known good version: unknown
- IDE: Visual Studio 15.7.2
- Platform Target Frameworks: 
  - iOS: 11
- Nuget Packages:
  - Xamarin.Forms: 3.0.0.482510
- Affected Devices:
  - iOS 11 Devices

### Screenshots
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29125873/40353475-e2c5ed70-5db1-11e8-9939-a3ef0e980544.png)

### Reproduction Link
```
var page = new ContentPage()
			{
				ToolbarItems =
				{
					new ToolbarItem{Icon = "bank.png"},
					new ToolbarItem{Icon = "calculator.png"},
					new ToolbarItem{Icon = "coffee.png"},
					new ToolbarItem{Icon = "bank.png", Order = ToolbarItemOrder.Secondary},
					new ToolbarItem{Icon = "calculator.png", Order = ToolbarItemOrder.Secondary},
					new ToolbarItem{Icon = "coffee.png", Order = ToolbarItemOrder.Secondary},
				}
			};

			return new NavigationPage( page);
```
https://bugzilla.xamarin.com/show_bug.cgi?id=59868
https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/pull/1208

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "the screen reader doesn't read text on screen like label's and other images, It only reads interactive elements like buttons." (#1946) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### The screen reader is not reading non interactive element like Labels and Images. If you have any sample code which can help me with this, please share that.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a label and provide AutomationProperties
2. Start the narrator for Windows 10 or JAWS 18
3. Run the project on Local Machine.

### Expected Behavior
The narrator should read the text written in the Label, Image or any other non interactive element if AutomationProperties are set in that control.

### Actual Behavior
The narrator is ommiting the text written in the Label, Image or any other non interactive element.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 2.5.0.280555, 2.3.4.231, 2.4.0.282 (checked with these three versions)
- Last known good version: none of the provided stable version are working with narrator
- IDE: Visual Studio 2015 update 3
- Platform Target Frameworks: Currently working with UWP only
  - UWP:  Windows  App Target vesion Windows 10(10.0; build 10240)
- Android Support Library Version: <!-- if applicable -->
- Nuget Packages: Xamarin Forms

###Code Snippet used is attached in the file attached
[Accessibility.txt](https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/files/1746927/Accessibility.txt)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[msbuild] Fix build with Xcode 10 beta 1." (#4182) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Many years ago (in Xcode 7 according to code comment)
Developer/Platforms/iPhoneOS.platform/Developer/usr disappeared, and we coped
by looking at Developer/usr instead (and also the subsequent code to locate
the bin directory was based on the location of the usr directory).

Developer/Platforms/iPhoneOS.platform/Developer/usr reappeared in Xcode 10
beta 1, but it seems useless (for one it doesn't contain a bin directory), so
in order to try to keep things sane don't look for this directory in Xcode 10
and instead go directly for Developer/usr (which is what we've been using as
the usr directory for years anyway).

Fixes this problem when building apps with Xcode 10 beta 1:

      /Library/Frameworks/Mono.framework/External/xbuild/Xamarin/iOS/Xamarin.iOS.Common.targets(626,3): error : Could not locate SDK bin directory [/Users/rolf/Projects/TestApp/test-app.csproj]

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Bump mono to head of 2018-02 + fix mtouch/mmp (#4171)" (#4181) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Backport from master

Commit list for mono/mono:

* mono/mono@1c24c158b0c [bitcode] Fix the generation of invalid llvm IR for some Span code.
* mono/mono@a49a68c6d7a [interp] Fix native to interp transition (#8957)
* mono/mono@92e11812f41 [System.Runtime.Serialization] Makes more APIs work for mobile
* mono/mono@260676f948e Bump API snapshot submodule
* mono/mono@eefdf4ed319 Bump external/cecil to b6c50e3
* mono/mono@0754926394c [2018-02] Finalize merp integration (#8869)

Diff: https://github.com/mono/mono/compare/7bdb7dd76582f305f86e35ac7bfe120d68557954...1c24c158b0cc0647adf216fd2244a094ce437611

* [mtouch][mmp] Have CoreResolver check for the new SymbolsNotMatchingException from Cecil

* [tests] Rebuild MX4175 in a separate .app to avoid debug symbol warnings

The newer cecil version is better at detecting incorrect .mdb, like the
test is using, resulting in warnings since the 2nd build (same location)
was done without symbols (so old ones were loaded).

Stale debug symbols is not the goal of the MX4175 test. Rebuilding the
.app in another directory solves the extra warning issue.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Add support for building on Jenkins. (#4159)" (#4180) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Add support for building on internal Jenkins.

Jenkins has been configured to build every branch on xamarin/xamarin-macios that contains a `jenkins/Jenkinsfile`, which means it will start working as soon as this PR is merged.

Results will be posted as statuses on each commit, which can be viewed using the url `https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/commits/<branch>`:

![screenshot 2018-06-01 11 12 57](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/249268/40832932-c3b05eb0-658c-11e8-9670-8de5fcc23407.png)

* The `continuous-integration/jenkins/branch` status links to the jenkins job.
* The other two are XI and XM packages (the `Jenkins-` prefix will be removed once we officially switch from Wrench to Jenkins).

More detailed information will be added as a comment to each commit, which can be seen by clicking on the commit and scrolling to the bottom (url of the format `https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/commit/<sha1>`)

![screenshot 2018-06-01 11 14 33](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/249268/40833014-fd8772f4-658c-11e8-8a35-5df46bfb16c7.png)

Unfortunately GitHub does not display the commit statuses when viewing a single commit, so to view those statuses you'll have to view the list of commits (the `/commits/` url). Tip: it's possible to use `<sha1>` instead of `<branch>` (and vice versa for that matter) if you're interested in the statuses of a particular commit.

Pull requests will also be built (only from contributors with write access), but by default nothing will be done (the job will exit immediately, although a green check mark will still show up). Jenkins will **not** add a comment in the pull request in this case.

However, if the label `build-package` [1] is set for a pull request, the internal jenkins job will run (it will do everything except the local xharness test run: this includes creating and publishing packages, creating various diffs, run tests on older macOS versions, test docs, etc). A detailed comment will also be added to the pull request (see below for multiple examples), which means that there will be two Jenkins comments: one for the public Jenkins which builds every PR, and one for the internal Jenkins [2].

[1] I don't quite like the name of the label, because it doesn't get even close to explain all that will actually happen, but `run-on-internal-jenkins-and-create-package` is a bit too long IMHO... Also it's non-obvious that this is the label to apply if the reason for executing on the internal jenkins is some other reason (for instance to test a maccore bump). Other ideas:

* `run-internal-jenkins`: doesn't make it obvious that a package will be created (which is probably the most common reason to want to run on internal jenkins)
* We could have multiple labels that mean the same thing: `build-package`, `internal-build`, `run-internal-jenkins`, etc, but it's redundant and I don't quite like it either.
* Any other ideas?

[2] I'm noticing now that these two look quite similar and this might end up confusing (the main difference is that the comment from the public jenkins will say **Build success/failure** and **Build comment file:** at the top. If something goes wrong the failure will also show up differently). Should this be made clearer?

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Add support for building on Jenkins." (#4159) at xamarin/xamarin-macios
Events.RelatedBody:
Add support for building on internal Jenkins.

Jenkins has been configured to build every branch on xamarin/xamarin-macios that contains a `jenkins/Jenkinsfile`, which means it will start working as soon as this PR is merged.

Results will be posted as statuses on each commit, which can be viewed using the url `https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/commits/<branch>`:

![screenshot 2018-06-01 11 12 57](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/249268/40832932-c3b05eb0-658c-11e8-9670-8de5fcc23407.png)

* The `continuous-integration/jenkins/branch` status links to the jenkins job.
* The other two are XI and XM packages (the `Jenkins-` prefix will be removed once we officially switch from Wrench to Jenkins).

More detailed information will be added as a comment to each commit, which can be seen by clicking on the commit and scrolling to the bottom (url of the format `https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-macios/commit/<sha1>`)

![screenshot 2018-06-01 11 14 33](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/249268/40833014-fd8772f4-658c-11e8-8a35-5df46bfb16c7.png)

Unfortunately GitHub does not display the commit statuses when viewing a single commit, so to view those statuses you'll have to view the list of commits (the `/commits/` url). Tip: it's possible to use `<sha1>` instead of `<branch>` (and vice versa for that matter) if you're interested in the statuses of a particular commit.

Pull requests will also be built (only from contributors with write access), but by default nothing will be done (the job will exit immediately, although a green check mark will still show up). Jenkins will **not** add a comment in the pull request in this case.

However, if the label `build-package` [1] is set for a pull request, the internal jenkins job will run (it will do everything except the local xharness test run: this includes creating and publishing packages, creating various diffs, run tests on older macOS versions, test docs, etc). A detailed comment will also be added to the pull request (see below for multiple examples), which means that there will be two Jenkins comments: one for the public Jenkins which builds every PR, and one for the internal Jenkins [2].

[1] I don't quite like the name of the label, because it doesn't get even close to explain all that will actually happen, but `run-on-internal-jenkins-and-create-package` is a bit too long IMHO... Also it's non-obvious that this is the label to apply if the reason for executing on the internal jenkins is some other reason (for instance to test a maccore bump). Other ideas:

* `run-internal-jenkins`: doesn't make it obvious that a package will be created (which is probably the most common reason to want to run on internal jenkins)
* We could have multiple labels that mean the same thing: `build-package`, `internal-build`, `run-internal-jenkins`, etc, but it's redundant and I don't quite like it either.
* Any other ideas?

[2] I'm noticing now that these two look quite similar and this might end up confusing (the main difference is that the comment from the public jenkins will say **Build success/failure** and **Build comment file:** at the top. If something goes wrong the failure will also show up differently). Should this be made clearer?
